title: Snap together units for 3-D chain link rings

description.text: The original seemed to be hard to print.  Here are printable snap together subunits (hopefully).  Made by projecting a subunit to 2D...  In theory the units fit together correctly (as in the picture); however, this is not tested in the real world yet so proceed at your own risk.
Twelve sets of these are needed to make a sphere.  However, I recommend printing one set at a time the first time around to see if they fit together correctly.

author: Naelhem

title: Midui - open source MIDI pad
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is an open souce MIDI pad based on Adafruit's Mini UNTZtrument. The main aim of this project was to build a two-pad midi controller for Trellis PCBs. Starting from Mini UNTZtrument, I tried to redesign it and improve it a bit. The first thing I did was to add an extra Trellis PCB. This way, you can control each pad with each hand, making it easier to play and control. Also, I decided to switch the normal potentiometers for some sliding ones. Now you can change the values you have mapped just with your thumbs! Finally, I went for an eassier way to assemble it and nicer finish. This drove me to place all the counterbored holes on the bottom of the base, making the assembly in one direction while hidding all the screws at the same time. This is still a work in progress, so i would recomend you to wait for newer versions with better tolerances for a smooth fit. Hope you like it :) For further information visit Adafruit's Mini UNTZtrument Midi Controller here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:409733

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%

You will need to print:
1x Base.stl: it takes a some time to print so be patient. Also, you should know that you only have to use the two holes near the side and the one further to attach the Arduino. Do not use all of them!! The other one does not fit properly.
1x Top.stl: you must rotate it 180º before slicing.
2x Pad_holder.stl: here are attached the Trellis PCBs. They are symetric so one for each PCB.
4x Pot_encl.stl: I am using 4 10k sliding potentiometers, so you will have to print 4 enclousures for them. You may also need to sand them a bit (I'm working on it)

title: Modern Robotics Controller & ZTE Speed Cases

description.text:
These models are protective cases for the Modern Robotics controllers and ZTE Speed smartphone used in the FIRST Tech Challenge. Made by Team 4029, 2 Bits and a Byte, these cases reinforce the PowerPole and miniUSB connectors to ensure that wires do not lose connection during the Robot Game. The ZTE case uses a TETRIX MAX hub pattern.
During our first competition, we had some serious connection issues: over the five matches we played, the robot moved for about a minute total! While we didn't run into these problems practicing and driving during team meetings, the environment on the playing field was significantly more hectic. By designing and installing these cases, we have drastically improved our reliability; the robot has not disconnected during testing or in competition since they were attached.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

+0.2mm

Infill:

+30%

Notes: IMPORTANT: All of these models are designed to work with the XY compensation feature found in Slic3r. This feature compensates for the width of the nozzle when extruding model edges, so without it 6/32 screws do not fit in the holes and, more importantly, it is significantly harder to insert the controllers into the cases. Many paid slicer programs likely have this feature built in, and Slic3r has it available in the advanced settings. The CPDM case is a little difficult to configure because the holes flanking all the USB cables must not be supported but rather bridged, but the top of the case needs support because the bridge is too long (unless you have a legendary printer). The ZTE case should not use supports.

comments.text: Do you by any chance have the .stp or .prt files?
comments.author: trumpet18

comments.text: Want to print this, I use Slic3r but generally avoid using supports, thus not great with them. What settings did you tweak or what did you do to avoid the USB holed from being supported?
comments.author: jmattdayton

comments.text: For all models besides the CPDM, supports should not be necessary - just turn them off completely. However, due to the PowerPole bracing the CPDM case requires support. I'm unsure what Slic3r takes into account when it decides whether to support or bridge a gap, but even in the worst-case scenario where the USB holes are supported instead of bridged I've been able to remove all the supports. I think Pillar style support is the easiest to remove.

remixed_from.author: ahaidet
remixed_from.title: Mini Cross Bow with flat top (for easier printing)

description.text: I love the mini crossbow for cotton swab design - lots of fun. I noticed that the string wasn't deploying smoothly an evenly, so I rounded the edge for a better deployment. I also rounded the channel where the swab (or dart) goes and introduced a nut & bolt approach to attaching the trigger (there is an extra set in case one breaks). I would recommend a stronger material for these parts in particular. Please let me know if you have any other adjustment ideas! The small part is an adapter to mount a pushpin to a standard 3mm bamboo skewer - it has a spot for the pin to snap in and it's threaded on the other end, so you just have to screw it onto a cut skewer. Make sure to remove the 4 tiny supports on the adapter. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/fZ7ZTQNEbD5

description.text:
14/01/2016 : VW Trim Clip VW Part number: 357.867.646 - Not official copy. No Claim to be. Self Designed to closely resemble obsolete part. This is a design for a Clip no longer in manufacture. It was a design based on the parts I have in a 2000 SEAT Alhambra, though these are the same as Volkswagen Sharan, or Ford Galaxy. It is probably used in other VW Group cars. This is the design as it appears, I've not redesigned it for 3D Printing. Yet.
(3D PRINTABLE SELF SUPPORTING VOLKSWAGON (VW) SHARAN CLIP IS NOW HERE:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1274409) As this is not "exactly" the same as the VW clip I think we're safe to upload this. Enjoy, Remix, write "Tom" on it and upload it. No, wait, please don't do that!!! If you must remix it, I've included the ProE files here for you to rework. Please do something meaningful if you are doing a remix. Peace out. EUR ING Andy Southern, CEng,
aka BathRobotics. p.s. if you like this car part, why not download (or just view) the other designs I've done: 20/06/2016: VW Sharan / Alhmabra Rear Adjustment Handle http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1586975

title: Inductive Sensor Holder for Wilson Reprap Printer

description.text:
Made this for my Wilson TS printer.  I imagine it would work for other Wilson variations, it's not a long print by any means, so you can find out yourself.
I threw this together very quickly and it is based off of mrice's servo operated stop end for auto bed leveling.  This should hold a wide variety of sensors, but I used the LJ12A3-4-Z/BY.  I've included a photo of a wiring diagram so you can hook up your LJ12A3-4-Z/BY.  All you need is a LM7805 that you can get from RadioShack for $1.99, some wire, and a PNP Inductive Sensor (I used the LJ12A3-4-Z/BY).  The great news is that you do not have to change anything in your config.h to make this work if you previously have installed mrice's auto bed leveling.  The only thing that changes is your Z_PROBE_OFFSET, obviously, and that can be done using the display on the printer itself.  If you have not enabled auto bed leveling, googling "LJ12A3-4-Z/BY 3d print" will bring you to an instructibles on how to do so. 
NOTE:  Do not follow the wiring guide on the instructible.  I have shown the proper way to wire it so you do not fry any components!!
Just a comment.  So far the repeatability of using the sensor, compared to a servo operated end stop, is far far superior.  If you are using the other bed leveling system I highly recommend you upgrade your bed to aluminum and buy a sensor.  The cost is fairly low ($4 sensor, $20 bed), but it really cuts out a lot of the BS that you hoped to cut out originally when installing the servo-switch setup.

Printer:

Wilson TS

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Notes: I used 0.4mm nozzle to print this.

Life counter (or counter for anything else) for Magic: The Gathering, Pokémon, etc.  As you take damage, desperately suck down a healing potion, or become the lucky recipient of a strength enchantment, just rotate the appropriate wheel and show your opponents exactly how vital you are.
The outer shell is a single piece and I've printed many of them without support, despite the short 90 degree bridges.  There are two .STL files for each of the left and right wheels -- one file for the wheel, one file for the numbers.  
I didn't upload files for the name plates because I doubt that every Thingiverse user wants my name on his/her game accessories.  The dimensions of the name plates are 35.5 x 10 x 1.  If you print a plate with those dimensions it'll fit into the recesses fairly tight, but I'd recommend gluing in.

FlashForge Dreamer

No

Supports:

No

.2mm

20%

Notes: Nothing fancy about the print settings here. The text might come out a bit crisper by printing at .15 or .1mm, but at .2mm it looks fine to me and prints quite quickly.

I used OpenSCAD for this.  The decagon shape was created by rendering cylinders with $fn=10.  The challenge here is that the diameter of the decagon is not the same as the diameter of a circle that's been forced into a decagon shape, hence, I had to guess and trial-and-error a bit to translate the numbers to the correct positions in the decagon faces.  My math skillz were not competitive with my impatience at this point.

title: TFA G R A F L E X Lightsaber

description.text:
GRAFLEX The Force Awakens flash body. The weapon of a Jedi Knight. This is more an attempt to replicate the prop, than to do an idealized version of Luke's lightsaber. This based on the basic layout of a Graflex flash unit. ****UPDATED 5/25/16:
Added an actual "bottom" to the rear/bottom tube, so it is now closed. Finally! ****UPDATED 3/15/16: "Accurized" the bends on the bunny ears* ****UPDATED 2/29/16:
Fixed main body - both halves. Should be a smoother tube overall, plus the front half has been lengthened to ~5.875 to match original. Previous part was too short. ***UPDATED 2/23/16: Uploaded new parts for main body - front and back. New tubes are thicker, have thicker tabs for the bunny ears as well. The interior of the tubes are now also clean, no flash leftover from the holes. There is a support included between the tabs on the body that will need to be removed before bunny ears are installed. (No need to print 100% infill, these are meant to be hollow so the emitter will fit in the end.) May require supports to print. I have now printed all files and assembled to one complete hilt (photos soon). The top and bottom buttons are tight squeeze, but they do fit. Make sure the slots on the two halves of the body are clean and clear, and the clamp should fit just fine. Note that you will have to trim the lower circle from the emitter pin in order to fit it in place. --The way the to halves fit together uses the slots on the body in conjunction with the slots on the clamp - slide and twist. You will need screw/double sided tape to affix the grips to the body, as well as screws/bolts to attache the d-ring/and it's clamp. A small metal pin (paper clip?) will be needed to affix the bunny ears to the tabs on the body. The side pins should fit in the holes on the side of the body, but it might be tight. Hot glue works well. The pin and lever on the clamp is an experiment, on paper it looks nice, however you may need to actually use a thin screw/nut &bolt to secure it. This is a work in progress, files may change in the future, though I'm confident this is close to a finished product.

title: Little Printed Cars: 2CV tribute
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The Citroen 2CV was a wonderful example of a radical but honest approach to car design - as it's rarely seen anymore, if ever. This 3d-printable design is not an attempt to recreate that car; it's simply my interpretation of design elements shown in various versions of it, notably, the 1939 prototype shown in one of the images above.
So I know, a real car usually has at least a front window. But the single headlight really was in those first 2CV prototypes, for cost- and weight reduction purposes. The car is printed on its side to enable the 'captured' wheels to rotate, without assembly (not sure who invented that approach, but big thanks!). The default size is roughly scale 1:30 compared to a real car. That's a nice size, but it can take a bit long to print. I've successfully printed versions at 70% and 50%, they turn out very cute too. A heads up: depending on what I end up doing with it commercially, this model may only be on Thingiverse temporarily - so best to grab it while you can. website http://michielcornelissen.com
facebook http://facebook.com/MichielCornelissenOntwerp
twitter http://twitter.com/michiel_ontwerp
newsletter http://eepurl.com/wkkFf
After printing, carefully loosen the wheels from the build platform first, and then the body, or you might break the axles.

title: Retrofit Nozzle wiper for mounting a Lulzbot Mini style bed wiper to a Taz or other printer

description.text: This is just a bracket to mount a Lulzbot mini style nozzle wiper (which you can download from here: http://download.lulzbot.com/Mini/1.01/production_parts/printed_parts/wiper_mount_Mini/ You will need two m3 heat set inserts, a pair of M3 bolts to mount it (8mm long), and another pair of M3 bolts to mount the assembly to the bed (also 8mm). Use the assembly as a guide for drilling then tapping 2 M3 bolt holes, or if you have room, a smooth hole and a nut on the bottom. There is support material on the bottom of the notch that needs to be removed, but it's built in so you don't have to generate it. Wiper 2 is a taller version of Wiper 1, for taller beds. Either one should work.

description.text:
This is a simple adapter that snaps onto a BD 3 ml syringe, allowing the plunger to be pulled back before injecting (also known as "aspirating"). Many doctors recommend this, but it is difficult to do, especially when self-injecting (and even more especially when your other hand is busy with something like z-tracking). Aspirating can be useful to verify that you are not injecting directly into a blood vessel, but there is a lot of disagreement about whether aspirating is good, and exactly how to do it. Follow your doctor's advice, and ask him/her if a gadget like this would be something you should use. For what it's worth, my doctor had an amused expression when I showed it to her, but she said it was fine if I wanted to use it. She didn't mention nominating me for a Nobel Prize in medicine, but maybe she was just busy that day. Improvements:
I should have beveled at least the bottom corners, so they don't run into the fingers that are holding the barrel. I would rather have a more positive lock on the plunger disc, rather than just a friction fit. I had trouble thinking of something that would be printable, though. It would be nice if it could accommodate a wider range of syringes. It's awkward removing it before dropping the needle in the sharps bin. A better way of attaching and detaching would be nice. Disclaimer:
I'm not a doctor, and even if I were, you didn't pay me. I don't know you, and I don't know what is good for you. I'm not saying to take any particular medication in any particular way. Do not use this device, or any other device, if it is illegal where you are. Do not take any medications unless a real doctor tells you to. Do not use this device while under the influence of drugs (other than I suppose the drugs you're using it to inject). Do not handle high voltage electricity while using the device. Do not allow children to play with needles. Do not give children alcohol, firearms, or chainsaws, even if they ask politely. Do not apply needles directly to your eyeball. And would it kill you to call your mom every now and then? I mean, she only gave you life, that's not a big deal or anything, right?

Designed in FreeCad. I uploaded the FreeCad projects to make it easier to modify. The final assembly is in asp4.fcstd, and the full parts and original sketches are in asp3.fcstd. Improvements welcome.

description.text:
Whilst designing my own CNC from scratch after being hooked by the mostly printed CNC I decided one thing I had to have was a method to fine adjust the bed work area other than the legs. As can be seen from the photo I have used 40mm M8 and plenty of adjustment available board pictured is 18mm MDF.
So here is my simple solution the bed can be adusted at 4 corners and if necessary middles too by use of top and bottom m8 nut and bolt.
Simple but effective I will be combining and incorporating into the feet of MY MP_CNC in the future when time allows and will upload that version when done.

No

0.25

60%

Using Slack off both screws and level by adjusting bottom screw before locking in place with top screw. As many or as few as required can be used on larger beds one or more adjusters could be used along each side to take out warping.

description.text: Update: the latest version of this template holder can be found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2329005 A remix of my original template stand, for larger templates produced by third parties. The dimensions for the slots on this stand are 22 x 4 mm. These dimensions shrink on printing, depending on how fine your settings are, so your mileage my vary. If you have printed the original stand, and your third party templates do not fit, try this one, and give the original one to someone who uses the cardboard, or smaller third party, templates. These settings work on my da Vinci, using ABS. I have been advised by others that these settings don't work so well for PLA. I would suggest that, when printing in PLA, you make the shells as thick as possible, as these are the only real component of the print. Update: I have changed the CC license for this thing. It is now CC-attribution-non-commercial-share alike. If you are presently printing and selling this thing (or plan to), I would ask that you contact me, and let me know you are doing so, or intend to do so. I have no intention of challenging your use of this thing, but would like to know who is printing it, and where they are in the world, from a purely narcissistic perspective... :)

I know that it doesn't print quite right in Cura unless you use the "Keep open faces" option in "Expert Settings". Without that option, the bottom half of the print won't be there - so it will try to start the print 15mm above the print bed. Make sure you verify the layer slices.

title: 16mm Carbon Fiber Tube Mount for DJI Flamewheel

description.text: The original design wasn't a solid and had some issues that prevented it from printing. This is the fixed version - faces were reversed, duplicate faces removed, and the object is manifold in Sketchup and in Simplify 3D. Sketchup file provided for anyone who wants to work on it further. UPDATE 2016/01/12: This item, as is, won't work to replace the mounts for the Aerial Mob arms. I've reworked it and am running a test print now. If you want to use it for Aerial Mob arms (with M3 and M4 screws), don't use this one. This one uses M2 screws for the plates (?) and M3 screws for the boom clamp. UPDATE 2016/01/15: I've abandoned trying to get this to work for my Disco Pro. I'll leave it up here for anyone else who wants to work with it.

author: students

print_settings.Printer:: Da Vinci 1.0A hacked with E3D-v6 and Repetier V92

description.text:
Rearview mirror supports for Da Vinci 1.0. This holds a piece of 6mm mirror in the back of your machine so you can see what's happening with your extruder behind your print carriage while it's in action. Pretty handy.
Print one of each left and right.

Printer:

Da Vinci 1.0A hacked with E3D-v6 and Repetier V92

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

20%

Instructions Cut a piece of scrap mirror 6mm [0.25 inch] thick x 310mm [12.25 inch] x 51mm [2 inch]. I just went to a local glass shop and asked what they had. 6mm is a standard thickness for bathroom mirrors and such. They pointed me to the dumpster and there were scraps in there that I cut down with a $6 glass cutting tool I got at Lowes. First time I ever tried to cut glass, it was super easy to do. Wear gloves and safety goggles - it's glass, it's sharp and you can't be too safe with your eyes. Slip the mirror into the clips. Put some electrical tape over the exposed edges for safety and to protect your cable bundle that may rub across it. Push firmly until the clips snap into place. You may find that you want to remove the left most screw for the Z axis rod mount for clearance while installing. If you are using Repetier firmware you will want to disable the top lid switch. You can easily do that: [Config]-[Firmware EEPROM Confirguration] and set "Top Sensor On" to zero. If you're not able to turn off the top sensor you can just put something in the lid switch sensor on the right side of the machine. The little black scraper that comes with the machine works pretty well there. That's it. Hope you find it useful.

description.text: Hexagonal Parametric Boxes made of hexagons. Similar to Parametric Boxes made of Hexagons - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1255039 but hexagonal in shape instead of rectangular. The basic parameters are the length of one of the sides of the base, the height of the box, and the thickness of the walls. One can also choose the size of the hexagonal holes and there are options that allows for the doubling of the patterns on the base and sides. Patterns like those created by thing:1238533 - Rotating Six Fold Ornament - can be used to make the base of the container. OpenSCAD code is included.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Resolution:

o.2 mm

The base of container.stl is made completely of hexagons.  Container_3, 12, and 22 have bases created from 2 sets of hexagonal arrays, one of which was rotated by 3, 12, or 22 degrees about z.  The two arrays were combined to make the bases of the containers.    See the image above - as the angle of rotation increases the pattern grows more complex.

author: luna1324

title: DNA/RNA Building Set/Transcription and Translation Model

description.text:
**See video to view the kit in action!
This set is designed to allow students to learn about DNA and RNA through playing with the blocks as well as to serve as a manipulative to model processes that involve DNA (described below) Each nucleotide block shows the letter symbol and shape of its corresponding base (either a purine or pyrimidine). The posts and holes at the top of each piece represent the number of hydrogen bond donors (the posts) and acceptors (holes) that each base has. The number and type of the hydrogen bond donors and acceptors determine which bases are able to pair in a DNA molecule.
The nucleotide blocks link together at the bottom in order to form the DNA or RNA backbone. The tops of each block can connect together to show hydrogen bonding with a complementary DNA or RNA strand. Blocks are designed so that only the correct pairs can connect (A with T, A with U, G with C). Kids can learn about the structure of DNA and base pairing just by figuring out how the blocks can and cannot fit together without any previous instruction.
The tRNA models are included so that the kit can be used to show the processes of transcription and translation. After making a model of double stranded DNA, the strands can be split and a complimentary mRNA strand can be built (substituting uracil for thymine). This mRNA strand is then removed. The anticodon on the tRNA models can be customized by inserting a sequence of three nucleotide blocks that pair with the sequence on the mRNA strand. Each anticodon matches a different amino acid block that can be linked to the top of the tRNA model. The tRNA models can then be bound to the mRNA strand and the amino acid blocks linked to form a protein. (See video for how this sequence works).
The set can also be used as a way to teach how DNA mutations such as deletions, insertions, and frame-shifts affect the final amino acid sequence for the protein coded by the DNA.
A blocking group is also included in order to demonstrate how DNA sequencing is done.

Printer:

Da Vinci Jr.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

5-10%

Notes: Rafts and supports are only needed for printing the nucleic acid blocks.
NGSS CCSS

Objectives: Students will be able to describe the way in which nucleotides hydrogen bond in specific pairs.
Students will be able to describe what happens to DNA structure when a base pair is mis-matched.
Students will be able to build complimentary DNA and mRNA strands to a pre-built template DNA strand.
Students will be able to describe the processes of transcription and translation.
Students will be able to describe the process by which proteins are made from DNA
Students will be able to describe the different roles RNA can play (mRNA, tRNA, rRNA)
Students will be able to describe the difference between purines and pyrimidines.
Students will be able to describe the different ways that DNA can mutate (deletions, insertions, etc.) and how these effect the final protein product.
Students will be able to recognize start, stop codons, as well as be able to describe how each tRNA has a specific anticodon that codes for only one amino acid. Preparation and pre teaching: Students should be familiar with nucleic acid base pairing as well as the basic properties and structures of DNA, mRNA, tRNA, and ribosomes. The kit can be used to teach concepts such as transcription, translation, base pairing, DNA replication, mutations, etc so exactly what needs to be pre-taught will depend on how the blocks are being used. Students can also be given the kit with very little explanation and allowed to figure out the structure of DNA and relationships between the nucleotides on their own.

***See video below for video of the lesson described below. The following is a description of how transcription and translation can be modeled using the set. As described in the summary, the set can be used to model a wide variety of concepts for DNA and RNA. Create a template DNA strand from the blocks. (You can choose the sequence of DNA to reflect a specific sequence of amino acids as well as a stop codon if you want to focus on protein structure or the effects of mutations on the final protein). Students must use the nucleotide blocks to create a complimentary mRNA strand that can leave the nucleus and go to the ribosome.* Either set up the needed tRNA molecules with the correct anti-codons and amino acids attached or have students create these. Demonstrate how the first tRNA binds to the mRNA while it is in the ribosome, moves over, then the next one binds. The amino acids then transfer to the new tRNA and the old one leaves. This process then repeats. Compare how different DNA sequences lead to different amino acid sequences. Additional Lessons:
-mRNA processing steps can also be integrated into this lesson
-The effects of mutations on transcription and translation, such as deletions and frame shifts, can be illustrated with the model.
No materials besides the model kit are needed.

comments.text: The file is fine on my end. To help me diagnose the problem, which slicer, printer, and nozzle diameter are you using.

comments.text: I am using a Flashforge Finder 3D Printer with Flashprint software to slice.  Nozzle diameter is .4mm.  I printed more than 20 pieces of the Guanine file, 6 at a time.  They printed and fit perfectly.  However, when I did exactly the same with the Cytosine file, that is when I discovered it had a missing male arm.  As noted earlier, I repeated the whole process again, duplicating 6 at a time, then one at a time, with the same result.  I had first downloaded the files individually, so I went back and downloaded all in a zip folder.  I tried again and the same result, the male arm is missing from the Cytosine. The rest of the Cytosine prints perfectly, only it has the perfectly squared off arm for the male side.  I tried loading the file to Autodesk 123D, scaling it to the same size and saving it to an STL file.  When I printed it, it was exactly the same as the original defective cytosine file with no male arm.
comments.author: chemteacher628

comments.text: I just tested the file with Flashprint and the male connector is showing up before and after slicing. One thing you could try is increasing the permitter overlap percentage to something over 30%. Additionally, make sure that the nozzle diameter is correctly set to 0.4mm.
comments.author: JBPowell

comments.text: Thanks for taking a look at this problem.  Did you actually print the cytosine file?  It is a strange problem.  The graphic on the Flashprint bed looks good with the male and female connector ends, however printing it using PLA squares off the male end.  There is no cut-out to make the male part. This same thing occurs when I test printed Uracil, Adinine and Guanine.  Only Thiamine prints properly.  The Flashforge Finder bed that I am using is approximately 6 inches square and the Thiamine file I am printing with PLA is only one inche at the base, so there is plenty of overlap.  I checked the nozzle setting and the Thiamine that prints correctly is the same as the Cytosine that does not.  However, I changed the nozzle size to .3mm and .4mm and test printed it again.  It did not print correctly.  I am stumped.
comments.author: chemteacher628

comments.text: The mystery problem of the cytosine file not printing the male connecting side has been solved. The design of the male side does not go all the way to the bed of the 3D printer like the female side.  When you print many (up to 9) units on the bed you look to see if all is printing correctly and stop the print to keep from wasting filament if you see a flaw.  In this case the male side does not print in the beginning scans like the female side.  The male side is off the bed so it does not print until several scans later, so it looks like there is a flaw and you stop the print.  That is what I did, stopped the print before it was completely printed.  By letting the print go to completion, the male end prints off the bed with a sag, but is workable.  Sorry to have raised the issue.  I am very pleased to find that I can now go ahead and print this excellent design.
comments.author: JBPowell

comments.text: That's great to hear that you solved the problem. If you add supports below the male end, it will prevent the sagging issue and the nucleotides will fit well together.
comments.author: JBPowell

comments.text: I've been printing it with an 0.5mm TAZ6 on medium/high quality settings, and the jig-saw puzzle design on the sides are a VERY tight fit.  Even after lowering extrusion and increasing retraction just a bit, it's tight.  Looking at the dimensions, there's little to no room for printer error, so I suggest making them just a little more loose depending on the person downloading it.  Even on fine with ABS or ngen, it still is a tight fit.  I've printed it in PLA just to see, and it doesn't work at all depending on the brand used.  Just thought I'd share that tip! :)

Step 5: Post your work. (NOTE, you can't call it your work if you don't work on it in One or more of these programs.)  
If you want to work on it in "Tinkercad" you may have some artifact issues when you import your .STL file.

description.text: Spaceship
from mmf

I was having some problems with M3 nuts not fitting into printed parts. The outside dimensions were fine, but the nut holes were too small due to thermal expansion or bad slicing path or whatever. So I printed this; it makes 5 six-sided holes. The first one is 3mm radius, the second adds 5%, then 10%, then 15%, and lastly 20%. You print it and try placing the nut to see what settings you should use for the desired fit; then you know how much to oversize nut holes for mechanical prints.
For my printer with Slic3r, adding 20% to hole diameter (10% to radius), yields a nut sized hole that is very difficult to push the nut in by hand. Tapping with a hammer or using plyers yields a nice snug fit. Adding another 10% to diameter (5% to radius) yields a nut sized hole that I can push the nut into by hand, but still snug enough for typical mechanical prints. 
You could adjust the scad file to make smaller increments if you want to get more exact or print more nut holes.

This multi-piece bridge building kit is ideal for learning in a fun and useful way! There are 4 different pieces in this set, anchor pieces which are the anchor points for the bridge. The beams which are used as the main building piece for the bridge, the pins which hold all pieces together and hold the beams to the anchors, and lastly the brace pieces to hold the sides of the bridges together (depth wise). There are several possibilities of what type of bridge to create and you can challenge yourself to make longer and increasingly skilled designs, the only limit is your creativity. Note for size : bridge beams are 10cm long by 1cm wide
anchor is 1.5cm by 5cm by 4 cm EDIT : a second "pin" design is on its way, the new pin will be 12mm long in order to fit through 4 layers of beams which may be necessary at some point depending on design.

This build your own bridge kit was designed using Creo parametric. The design process started by some reflection on what my favorite part of school as a child was, that was easily the design and tech where we could physically building something.  Using this concept,  I pieced together a project in my mind in which one could uniquely design their own creation using standard pieces.  After some trial and error on Creo (3d modeling software) these modular pieces that could be combined in many different ways came about. When designing the parts it was important to keep in mind to keep it so everyone could have their own unique design.

Project: Custom Bridge Building Kit Objectives: There are many different things to be learned in the designing of a bridge some learning outcomes are as follows:
1) Strongest shapes - squares, rectangles, triangle what works best for a bridge?
2) What are some important things to keep in mind when designing a bridge (or any project in general) i.e: how much material do you have? What are the criteria that the bridge needs to meet? etc?
3) how to apply what they learn in class to real life ie: which angles work best for certain needs? How to measure properly, etc
Audiences: Grade 7-8 , no prior skill level or understanding of engineering or design is needed.
Preparation: In order to prepare for this project students could google and research real life bridges and look at pictures and find out what bridges look like and different types of designs.
Steps:
This kit allows students to design their own unique bridge and learn about the strengh of triangles, and other basic engineering concepts. This allows students who may not do well in traditional subjects to try their hand and potentially flourish at a new skill.
1) The students would most likely be grouped up in pairs or groups of 3.
2) each group would receive an exact number of parts ie : 10 beams, 3 anchors and 20 pins.
3) the groups read over the criteria ie: the bridge must be 20cm long and be able to hold 200 grams.
4) The design, building and testing period - groups get to design and test their bridges over and over until they are happy with their design
5) presenting their design - present the design to the class, explain why they they chose their certain design and what its strengths or weakness may be ie: strength: it is very strong, weakness: uses to much material. Could also bring the students on the 3d printing part as well and they get to choose what the fill level and quality setting their pieces are printed on. Result: By the end of the activity students should have designed and built their own custom bridge and learned basic design concepts and gotten the chance to share their ideas with fellow classmates. The assessment could be based on several parts 1) how they work in a group situation 2) the presentation to their fellow peers 3) if their bridge fits all the design criteria or not 4) the overall design of bridge / how it looks aesthetically.

author: mattr254

description.text:
These are the defense pieces for the 2016 USFIRST.org robotics game, FIRST Stronghold. Included are one of each of the 9 defenses:
  • Group A: Portcullis (no lift gate included) and Cheval de Frise (no movable parts)
  • Group B: Moat and Rampart
  • Group C: Drawbridge and Sally Port (no movable parts)
  • Group D: Rock Wall and Rough Terrain
  • Low Bar (Has the curtain, but is of hard plastic)
    • They are intended to give you a feel for how the game pieces look in real life and for a small scale testing of sample robots. They are modeled at 1/25.4 (1 inch => 1mm). This comes in handy because you can mock up a robot at the same scale and see that it can traverse the defenses. At this scale the pieces are a bit small. Printing them at double scale works but it takes quite a bit longer and may or may not be helpful. These models are built from the game manual and from the team version drawings. The measurements are very close, but don't expect them to be perfect when scaled up 25.4x. I'd love to see someone modify the actionable parts (portcullis, cheval, drawbridge, and sally port) so that they can be printed and move.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1mm recommended .2mm works

Infill:

~20%

Notes: The drawbridge and portcullis will print fine if your printer can bridge fairly well. If it can't, then you can print with supports.
The cheval has 23 degree angles. Your printer may have a problem with that.
The rest can be printed as is.

title: Makergear M2 V4 Hotend Easy Access Filament Drive Version 2

description.text:
Easy access filament drive for the Makergear M2 with a V4 hotend. I have incorporated a rotating nut that will allow you to rotate the machine screw out of the way in order to make it easy to remove the bearing section in order to access the filament.
This version has two slots for Machine screws in order to give a more even tension the filament idler bearing.
This is a Remix/Combination of the original Makergear V4 Filament Drive, incorporating the bottom latch part of Narosenberg's Easy access design.

Printer:

Makergear M2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm or 0.2mm

Infill:

50% or higher

To make the pivoting nut, I cut the non threaded part of a fairly long 1/4" Carriage bolt, and drilled and tapped it to accept two M3x0.5 socket head hex machine screw. The machine screw will need to be ~ 25mm in length. (I cut down longer ones to fit)
Be sure not to use a Grade 8 Bolt, as they are quite difficult to drill & Tap (I broke off my tap trying to thread one)

title: Stupid Simple Downward Cooling fan duct

description.text:
I find downward cooling to be VERY important in achieving high quality results.
After years of trying many different approaches to adding downward cooling to Rep1 style machines I decided it was time to do it in a way that meets all of my own requirements. These were:
  • Easy to install and remove VERY quickly to allow for fast access (i.e., no tear down) for clearing the filament path.
  • Use of a radial fan rather then a wimpy box fan.
  • Speed control
    Basically I use a sturdy hook and loop system to mount the unmodified radial fan directly to the face of the extruder carriage. Note... If you follow the instructions for using this tape you will see you need to give it at least 24 hours for the glue to cure. After that it will hold the fan on reliably and easily.
    Next I made a variety of duct styles and the best performer for downward cooling was the style which reaches in between the hot blocks and as such it will not last long so I did 2 others. Each is a fast print, making it simple to try each style. I used thin kapton tape on the inner lip of the duct which meets the fan to make the duct install with a pressure fit. If the duct crashes into a lifting print it will pop off easy before anything breaks. Easy to install, easy to remove! YAY!
    Lastly I power the fan with a 1amp variable voltage universal AC/DC converter. Fan and converter are 12v. I usually put it at around 9v. This approach is VERY effective for downward cooling.
    Be sure to mount the fan with the carriage all the way forward to ensure it clears the case.
    • This project and many other 3D printing subjects are discussed in detail in the 3D Printing Today Podcast:
    threedprintingtoday.libsyn.com or threedprintingtoday.com.
    If you have never listened to the show... Check it out! It's FREE! Here's urls to the main components:
    http://www.amazon.com/Connector-Cooling-Blower-50mmx15mm-Laptop/dp/B00MJU6JR2/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1452571081&sr=8-3&keywords=50mm+radial+fan
    http://www.amazon.com/3M-Reclosable-Fastener-SJ3560-Clear/dp/B00JHKTDMA/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1452571214&sr=8-2&keywords=plastic+hook+and+loop+tape
    http://www.amazon.com/Universal-Adapter-Polarity-Switchable-1000ma/dp/B009D5X0NW/ref=sr_1_12?ie=UTF8&qid=1452571264&sr=8-12&keywords=universal+Ac+DC+adapter

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm layer height

Infill:

10%

Notes: No raft, but i use internal support for a cleaner result.
DO NOT USE PLA OR ABS! I used PETG, but i may print again in Nylon. The edge of the duct gets right up against the hot block it WILL soften if not completely melt in time.

Created some quadcopter skids to fit a standard DJI 450 Frame. I used 15mm Diameter PVC pipe for the supports and M3 screws as the fasteners. Legs seem strong so far, I printed the mounts with Carbon fibre reinforced PLA but any material should be suited for the model.

This is designed to be used with this digital depth gauge: http://www.amazon.com/0-25mm-Black-Digital-Depth-Gauge/dp/B00G90R27E/ref=sr_1_25?ie=UTF8&qid=1452561577&sr=8-25&keywords=digital+depth+gauge Check around, you might find a cheaper one on ebay, but it'll probably ship from china. You can use two zip ties to mount the gauge. I designed this to mount where the extruder fan normally sits. The depth gauge should be lined up with the extruder, I expect this could be kept on the printer if you use the Cobra extruder fan, or some other rear mount fan.I haven't had the chance to print this out. It may need adjustments and is most probably over designed. Let me know if you have any suggestions for corrections.

Update:
Added V 1.5 based on feedback and testing. V 1.0 is pretty close to my nozzle so will likely melt and/or burst into flames at some point. YMMV. As much as I love the Half Stepper, I wasn't real keen on the nozzle. It seemed to blow straight down rather than angled toward the nozzle so as to cool the filament as soon as it is placed. There are many other annular airflow coolers out there, but I had very limited success remixing them for the FFCP and most would require that I refit or remove the Half Stepper. So here it is in all its rough-hewn glory. The original is available on TinkerCad (search Half Stepper circular nozzle).

comments.text:
Nice design! Just what I was looking for! But it seems to me that it is impossible to print this without supports, as the area around the nozzle is not connected to the top!
How did you print this? With supports? If yes: How did you remove the supports from the inside?
Thanks in advance!
comments.author: chrzr

comments.text: I used supports, but only connecting the print bed to the body; I didn't use any for the inside surfaces.  The angles are forgiving enough that you can print this without additional support on the inside of the body.

comments.text: Good luck!  Note that mine melted rather easily despite thermal shielding, so keep an eye on that!
comments.author: legreatmagnet

comments.text: Nice work, thanks for the re-mix! Just so you know, I purposely have it cool the filament as it exits the tip.  Cooling the nozzle itself can lead to problems like filament clogs, and poor adhesion.
comments.author: NeverDun

comments.text: Agreed, not to mention the added power of the cartridge trying to maintain the temp.  It just seemed that the effectiveness was marginalized by the travel direction (i.e., two of four sides would be cooled when moving one direction).  Something else I note with your original design is the ease of prototyping nozzles!  So much easier to tweak a nozzle design with a modular system than re-print and re-install each and every iteration of an entire assembly.
comments.author: NeverDun

comments.text: Exactly.  I almost made one that wrapped around two sides, but it seemed to work, so I left it.  Yours will probably work better when you get to very pointy objects where the nozzle I designed isn't quite making it to the hot plastic. The big deal everyone makes about turning the nozzle around during the conversion was supposed to improve coverage as well.  As long as there isn't too much back pressure, I think your design should work great!

title: OverEngineered Flashforge Creator Pro Spool Holders
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I really like the Spool Holders created by arghhh40k and have used them for quite some time.   But I had to go overkill and make new ones.  I just learned a little about AUTODESK 123D Design software and put these together.  Luckily you can easily add fillets and chamfers in 123D!!!  
I found that I needed about 10 or so mm longer posts for the sainsmart PET spool and other spools I've bought.   On these I extended the post, added a long taper, and reduced all stress concentrations by rounding all corners that might experience any stress.  Lastly, I added indented identification text of "Left Side Spool" and "Right Side Spool" just in case there's any question or if you're not sure which side the Rep G software (or the printer) identifies as left and right.
Three files are posted;  A file with both, and then one each for left and right if you would like to print them individually.
These print successfully in PLA with no raft and no support using Replicator G.  Don't go over 50° for the platform temp or you will see a lot of warp occur to the parts.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Fine STL, .2mm thick layers

Infill:

10% - 20%

Notes: Less than 10% infill makes the parts that fit into the printer feel flimsy. Try 95 deg C platform temp with ABS to reduce warpage vs. 110 C

I used AUTODESK 123D Design to make these parts. The nice thing about 123D Design is that it's free. Unlike Sketchup Make, its easy to add rounds, fillets and chamfers. You can also just lightly pull and push faces and edges to make more complex shapes, and the software actually works great doing these odd things without crashing. WOW!

comments.text: Does this design work with the FFCP 2016 edition or...?
comments.author: amarand

comments.text: I don't know for 100% sure but looking at the picture on Amazon for the newer FFCP it looks like the slots in the back of the unit for the spoolholders are the same size.  Why not measure on your FFCP and then open up the STL in a CAD program and check the sizing?  That or start printing one and stop it after the first layer,  then measure to be sure it will fit.
comments.author: amarand

comments.text: I'm guessing @amarand may have tried printing this by now but I just measured the hole and check the size on the file and it looks like it should fit perfectly. Thanks for the design, I'll have some new spool holders tomorrow.

title: Desk Mount For Hanging Lamp w/ Shade

description.text: I needed a lamp above my desk and didn't want to hang one from the wall or ceiling. The flange mounts to my desk behind my monitor. Cut the dowel rod in two making one piece longer than the other. Using the longest part out of the flange for height and the shorter to angle out over the desk. You will need a 1/2" x 36" dowel rod, a hanging lamp cord and an led light bulb. I had Spax #8 1 1/4" screws left over from another project so the flange is modeled for them but I'm sure will work with almost any screw. Note Depending on your hanging lamp cord I provided a clip for round cable and flat cable. Also do not use regular incandescent bulbs because of heat. You can use CFL that is less than 60w but I recommend the Great Value Led bulbs. Print the lamp shade with 0% infill and everything else at 15-20%. Will work with my PacMan light shades as well or any lamp shade made with the Fusion 360 Lampshade Tutorial. I am making a ring for the hanging lamp cords that are not threaded so the lamp shade doesn't slide down onto the bulb.

I created most of these letters while doing "The Saturday Killer" ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12592 ) I figured it would be nice to create a full-fledged font instead of just doing the letters that I needed. This font uses the layer thickness (pathT) and extrusion width (pathW) to create small two-color-friendly text. included are capital letters, numbers, and some simple punctuation. You can create the letters by themselves (a(), b(), etc...) or you can use the provided writeText and rotateText modules. There's also a helper spreadsheet that will create the OpenSCAD code for you. if you do the letters by themselves I highly recommend placing a cube behind your text to simplify skeining.
d = 2pathW
w = text length
h = 10pathT Update Oct19:
  • Fixed the shoddy construction (see discussion below)
  • Added two text-creation modules: writeText and rotateText. One of the things that irks me about the other OpenSCAD fonts is that each letter gets the same horizontal space, even if it's a thin letter (like "I".) I added a little more complexity to fix that. Instead of just specifying the letters and count, you also specify the horizontal offset for each letter. kind of a pain, BUT:
  • I added a code-creation spreadsheet. Just type in your words and a couple parameters, and the OpenSCAD code is automatically generated. It's an xls, but I checked and it imports well into google docs
    • Update Oct25:
  • Added numbers and some simple punctuation
  • removed "Work in Progress" status. If I end up doing lowercase and more punctuation, it will be in a derivative font.

Legit plotter pens for my HP DraftMaster are either old and dried out, or new and expensive.  Print these adapters and cut down the ink cartridges of normal pens and pencils to fit.
Bonus: you can use interesting inks like white and metallic.  Uniball Gel Impact are quite nice, and Sharpie has some nice metallics as well.
If you find other writing implements that would benefit from an adapter, send me the info and I'll make one up.

These are the parts needed to make your own custom Chording keyboard. It is currently a work in progress but I like where it is at. it is based on a common cheap button: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00NWFZCQC Version 2 of the button holder prints much faster and allows you to use a 4d size nail as a hinge point. it still uses the wire holder so that doesn't go to waste, but it allows you to position the switches any way you would like over an approximate 90° sweep (even better if you make your own button caps. With out the button caps it can swing from 0° (Both buttons flat holding the left button) to +90° (buttons facing in) to -60° (Buttons facing out). One hole for the pin is slightly smaller than the other 2 so that it latches in quite snug. Please let me know how your build does, if you decide to build a few.

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

No

Yes

Hollow

title: Tormach TTS ER20 Collet Wrench (for 30mm hex collet nuts)

description.text:
I bought some fancy Tormach TTS ER20 collets, only to find I didn't own a wrench big enough to tighten the 30mm collet nuts. Rather than run out and buy a wrench, I got out the 3D printer and made my own.
I have a small printer (Printrbot simple) so its a stubby wrench. The holes in the handle are simply to reduce the amount of PLA used. The wrench fits down well past the hex area to help alignment and reduce the possibility of the wrench slipping off.
So far it seems plenty strong enough for tightening ER20 collets.

title: Bowden Bracket for Gregs or Wades Extruders

description.text:
After having issues with direct drive extruders on my Rostock I wanted to go back to my old faithful Wades extruder.  
This bracket will allow you to turn a standard "J-Head" Gregs or Wades extruder in a Bowden arrangement. The hole at the top will take a 1/8" BSP Male to 6mm push fit pneumatic fitting and the two encapsulated nuts allow you to build the extruder before mounting to the printer.  
Note: It now looks like my direct drive issues were with the stepper driver not the extruder :-(

All too often in homes, offices and workshops cables / cords are run across spaces where people walk. As most cords are white / grey / black they can often be hard to see at a glance on similar coloured flooring. You can tape them down... but that's messy and can leave sticky marks, or you can cover them with a mat if you have one available but often don't. If this sounds like something that happens in your place then printing a couple of these may be well worth doing in the interests of safety. 
The 'Caution Cable Cover' measures approx. 150mm long / 60mm wide / 12.5mm tall. It features three slots that run underneath to accommodate most common size cords / cables. The design has been made to accept cables / cords up to approx.. 7.25mm which is a thick extension cord. Smaller cables can be sun through the slots but will not be held tightly in place like a thicker power extension cord. However, whether gripped by the cover or not the cables are routed safely and there is a visible 'CAUTION' warning on top of the cover. 
For extra wide spaces you can use two 'Caution Cable Covers'. It takes a matter of seconds to install the cables in the slots so a quick and easy way to improve safety at home / in your office / in your workshop.   
The design itself is tapered up over the cables which run through the three slots underneath. On top is the word 'CAUTION' which can be printed in an alternative colour by pausing the print near the end. With a 1mm Raft pause at 12mm or 95% progress for your colour change. . 
This is an easy print but does take 3 - 4 hours depending on your machine. Filament use will be around 60gm depending on settings. Print a couple in the interest of safety!
Note: If you like this check out my other practical and fun designs.... and post pictures!

Drill Out PCB I needed to drill out the PCB ever so slightly to get the M3 threads to fit in there. You could use a file, try and just twist em through. But I used a drill bit and it was fairly simple. Just hold it safely and securely while doing so.
